title: Implants for surgery — Active implantable medical devices — Part 1: General requirements for safety, marking and for information to be provided by the manufacturer
description: The foundational safety standard for active implantable medical devices (AIMDs) including pacemakers, neurostimulators, implantable pumps, cochlear implants, and circulatory support devices. Establishes general requirements for device safety, sterile packaging, labeling/marking, and accompanying documentation. Covers protection against electrical hazards, mechanical forces, heat, EMI, defibrillation, and other environmental stresses. Serves as the parent standard for the ISO 14708 series, with particular standards (Parts 2-7) supplementing or modifying these requirements for specific device types.
scope: Applies to active implantable medical devices powered by electrical energy or other sources (gas pressure, springs). Covers both implantable and non-implantable parts/accessories that could affect safety or performance. Type tests on samples demonstrate compliance. For devices with a particular standard (Parts 2-7), this general standard is not intended to be used alone.

sections.1: Scope - applicability to all AIMDs including electrically and non-electrically powered devices, implantable and non-implantable parts
sections.2: Normative references - ISO 8601, ISO 10993-1, ISO 11607-1, ISO 14155, ISO 14971, IEC 60068 series, IEC 60601-1, IEC 62304
sections.3: Terms and definitions - 40 defined terms including ACTIVE IMPLANTABLE MEDICAL DEVICE, BOS, EOS, RRT, PSP, LEAD, CATHETER, risk management terms
sections.4: Symbols and abbreviations - requires conformance with harmonized standards (e.g., ISO 15223-1) for symbols used in markings
sections.5: General requirements - IEC 60601-1 compliance for non-implantable parts, IEC 62304 software lifecycle, usability engineering, information security for wireless communication, ISO 14971 risk management, misconnection prevention
sections.6: Requirements for particular AIMDs - placeholder for device-specific requirements in Parts 2-7
sections.7: General arrangement of packaging - implantable parts supplied in non-reusable pack within sales packaging
sections.8: General markings - prominent warnings, traceability of implanted parts and components
sections.9: Markings on sales packaging - manufacturer info, device description, sterilization statement, dates, accessories, connector types, special purpose indication
sections.10: Construction of sales packaging - protection during storage/handling, humidity resistance, indelible markings, documentation association
sections.11: Markings on sterile pack - manufacturer, sterilization method, dates, device description, opening instructions
sections.12: Construction of non-reusable pack - ISO 11607-1 compliance, tamper-evident design, indelible markings
sections.13: Markings on the AIMD - manufacturer name, model/family name, serial/batch number, identification code readable without surgery
sections.14: Protection from biological effects - terminal sterilization (SAL 10⁻⁶), particulate matter limits, biocompatibility per ISO 10993-1, incorporated medicinal substances
sections.15: Protection from external physical features - IEC 60601-1 for non-implantable parts, no sharp edges on implantable parts
sections.16: Protection from electricity - IEC 60601-1 leakage current limits, DC current density ≤0.75 µA/mm², dielectric strength of insulated leads
sections.17: Protection from heat - implantable surface temperature ≤39°C (2°C above body temp), requirements for devices intended to supply heat
sections.18: Protection from ionizing radiation - sealed sources required, justification of radiation exposure, ALARA principle
sections.19: Protection from unintended effects - material aging, elective replacement indicator for non-rechargeable power sources, single fault analysis, side effects evaluation, medicinal substance compatibility, transcutaneous energy transfer
sections.20: Protection from external defibrillators - Test 1 (damped sinus 140V) and Test 2 (truncated exponential mono/biphasic) for implanted torso devices
sections.21: Protection from electrical fields applied to patient - diathermy and other electrical treatments, contraindication declarations
sections.22: Protection from miscellaneous medical treatments - diagnostic ultrasound immunity test (ISPTA ≥1500 mW/cm², 3.5 MHz), MRI compatibility declarations
sections.23: Protection from mechanical forces - drop test for hand-held/portable parts, vibration test (5-500 Hz random), shock test (500g), tensile/flexural requirements for leads/catheters, connector reliability
sections.24: Protection from electrostatic discharge - IEC 60601-1 ESD test on non-implantable parts, safe mode operation after ESD
sections.25: Protection from atmospheric pressure changes - withstand 70-150 kPa (approx. 3000m altitude to 5m water depth)
sections.26: Protection from temperature changes - IEC 60068-2-14 thermal cycling test (-10°C to +55°C default) on sterile-packed implantables
sections.27: Protection from electromagnetic non-ionizing radiation - immunity to EU General Public Reference Levels, risk assessment for EMI
sections.28: Accompanying documentation - comprehensive requirements for instructions for use, 30 subclauses covering manufacturer info, device characteristics, warnings, precautions, sterilization, disposal

Annex A.description: General guidance and rationale - detailed explanations for specific clauses including software validation, usability, information security, packaging, biocompatibility, defibrillation testing, ultrasound testing, mechanical testing, EMI

Annex B.description: Relationship between fundamental principles in ISO/TR 14283:2004 and the clauses of ISO 14708-1 - detailed mapping table showing how each fundamental principle is addressed

related_standards.description: Cardiac pacemakers - Particular requirements that supplement/modify this general standard for implantable pacemaker systems
Implantable neurostimulators - Particular requirements for spinal cord stimulators, deep brain stimulators, etc.
Implantable infusion pumps - Particular requirements for drug delivery implants
Circulatory support devices - Particular requirements for ventricular assist devices (VADs)
Implantable defibrillators (tachyarrhythmia) - Particular requirements for ICDs
Cochlear implant systems - Particular requirements for hearing implants
Risk management - Required for compliance with Clause 5.5; defines risk management process, risk analysis, evaluation, and control
Medical device software lifecycle - Required for software of AIMDs per Clause 5.2; defines software development process
Medical electrical equipment safety - Required for non-implantable parts per Clause 5.1; referenced throughout for test methods and requirements
Biological evaluation of medical devices - Required for biocompatibility assessment per Clause 14.3
Packaging for terminally sterilized medical devices - Required for non-reusable pack construction per Clause 12.1
Clinical investigation of medical devices - Referenced for side effects evaluation per Clause 19.4
MRI safety for patients with AIMDs - Technical Specification for MR compatibility testing referenced in Clause 22.2
Fundamental principles for implants - Annex B maps all requirements to these principles; terminology consistency per Note 4 of Clause 1
Usability engineering - Referenced for usability validation per Clause 5.3
Medical device symbols - Referenced for standardized symbols in markings per Clause 4
First edition - This second edition (2014) cancels and replaces the first edition with technical revisions

suggested_cross_references.note: Definition and scope. Includes single devices or systems with implantable and non-implantable components.
Requires ISO 14971 compliance. Includes risk analysis, evaluation, and control. Risk management file required.
Requires IEC 62304 compliance for AIMD software. Software must be validated.
Usability engineering process required for non-implantable parts. References IEC 62366.
Required for wireless communication with implantable part. Evaluate through risk management.
Implantable parts must be supplied sterile in non-reusable pack. SAL 10⁻⁶ required per 14.1.
Comprehensive marking requirements for sales packaging (9), sterile pack (11), and device (13).
ISO 10993-1 assessment required for parts contacting tissues, cells, or body fluids.
SAL ≤10⁻⁶ required. Validated sterilization process. ISO 11135-1, ISO 11137, ISO 17665-1, or ISO 14937.
Test method for counting particles. Vascular devices: ≤6000 particles ≥10µm, ≤600 particles ≥25µm.
DC current density at implantable electrode surface ≤0.75 µA/mm². IEC 60601-1 for external parts.
Test voltage ≥2x peak voltage after 10-day saline soak preconditioning.
Implantable surface ≤39°C (2°C above 37°C body temp) in normal operation or single fault.
Must be sealed sources. Justify radiation exposure. ALARA principle.
Required for non-rechargeable power sources. Defines RRT, PSP, and EOS intervals.
Single component/software failure shall not result in unacceptable risk. Document in risk management file.
Test 1 (damped sinus) and Test 2 (truncated exponential) at 140V through 300Ω. Timing in Figure 3, Table 1.
Contraindication declarations required. Document in accompanying documentation per 28.26.
Test at ISPTA ≥1500 mW/cm² (adjustable with attenuation factor), 3.5 MHz, 20% duty cycle, 3 min/position.
Manufacturer must declare MRI conditions. References ISO/TS 10974 Technical Specification.
Random vibration 5-500 Hz per 23.2. Shock 500g per 23.7. Drop test per IEC 60601-1 for portable parts.
Tensile, strain relief, and flexural requirements. Design analysis required.
Manufacturer declares performance. Quality shall not degrade during use. Re-connection possible.
IEC 60601-1 Clause 17 test on non-implantable parts. Must return to safe mode after ESD.
Withstand 70-150 kPa for 1 hour (approx. 3000m altitude to 5m water depth).
IEC 60068-2-14 Test Nb. Default -10°C to +55°C at 1°C/min. Test in sterile pack only.
Meet EU General Public Reference Levels (ICNIRP 1998). Risk assessment for EMI. Particular standards may add specific tests.
30 subclauses covering all required documentation. Includes warnings, precautions, device info, sterilization, disposal.
Point when AIMD first released by manufacturer as fit for placing on market.
Point when PSP has elapsed and performance to design specification cannot be assured.
When power source indicator reaches manufacturer-set value. Indicates entry into PSP.
Period device continues functioning beyond RRT. Manufacturer defines interval.
If AIMD incorporates medicinal substance, safety and quality must be verified. Special requirements for blood-derived substances.
Side effects evaluated by clinical data per ISO 14155 or published literature.
If used, shall not result in unacceptable risk. Document in risk management file.
